container-title: Sandow the Magnificent: Eugen Sandow and the Beginnings of Bodybuilding
publisher: The Muscular Life and Times of Eugen Sandow
title: Eakins’s Arcadia

Sandow’s body was literally petrified when it served as the model for a monumental white marble sculpture of the Battle of the Lapith and the Centaur completed in 1900 by Gustave Adolphe Crauck, which is still on display at the Mairie of the 6eme arrondissement in Paris. He was also cast in plaster for a short-lived exhibition at the forerunner to London’s Natural History Museum and served as the model for a bronze statuette designed by William Pomeroy in 1891, which is still awarded to champion bodybuilders

15 The competition presentation board describes the bands as “bandoni in ferro.” Etlin and Schumacher describe the iron band structure and isostatic line patterns. See Etlin, Modernism in Italian Architecture, 1890–1940, 432; and Schumacher, Surface and Symbol, 183. Doordan cites the ancient construction technique of opus reticulatum as a source for the isostatic lines. Francesco Tentori notes that the type of iron specified – 99.9 percent pure – was chosen for its ability to resist corrosion in perpetuity.
